Intro.label: Introduction
Intro.content: We are a multidisciplinary group using super-resolution microscopy in combination with machine learning to investigate molecular mechanisms of neuronal communication.

SuperResolution.label: Super-Resolution Microscopy
SuperResolution.description: Microscopy has revolutionized the biological sciences, but there are many biological questions that conventional microscopy is unable to answer due to the diffraction of light in conventional systems. A conventional light microscope is unable to visualize objects smaller than the diffraction limit of ~250 nm. Our lab uses and develops super-resolution microscopy methods to visualize objects smaller than the diffraction limit in both fixed and living cells.

MachineLearning.label: Machine Learning
MachineLearning.description: We develop machine learning methods to optimize image acquisition and analysis. In particular we develop Reinforcement learning, Active learning as well as supervised and unsupervised learning methods.

Neuro.label: Cellular and Molecular Neuroscience
Neuro.description: We use optical nanoscopy to explore several aspects of neuronal structure and function. Our areas of interest include synaptic protein localization, mitochondrial dynamics, and functional imaging.

Alexis.name: Alexis Lebrun
Alexis.info: Graduated in Engineering Physics in 2018, I am currently pursuing a PhD in biophotonics at the CERVO and COPL (Centre d'Optique, Photonique et Laser) research centers. My project is ambitious and combines several disciplines in engineering and neuroscience, including nanomaterials, deep learning, super-resolution microscopy and microfluidics. I aim to develop a highly sensitive, machine-learning assisted molecular identification method that will allow real-time identification and differentiation of biomarkers of gut permeability in microfluidic devices that closely mimic the gastrointestinal tract environment. I am also trying to implement this technique in a super-resolution microscope to realize super-resolved molecular images.

Alexy.name: Alexy Pelletier-Rioux
Alexy.info: Super-résolution de la Cofiline lors de la formation des fibres d'actine.

Andreanne.name: Andréanne Deschênes
Andreanne.info: My PhD project consists in designing a multimodal super-resolution microscope which we will use to study how proteins reorganize in neurons when the strength of their connections is altered by activity. We also aim to use this microscope to investigate the influence of diet on the permeability of the gut.

Anthony.name: Anthony Bilodeau
Anthony.info: My PhD project consists in building a super-resolution microscope that will be able to adapt to the sample using reinforcement learning. During my master, I developed weakly-supervised techniques to facilitate the analysis of microscopy images.

AntoineG.name: Antoine Girard
AntoineG.info: Mon baccalauréat en biochimie a permis de mettre en évidence ma passion pour la biologie moléculaire et les neurosciences. Mon projet de ma maîtrise en neurosciences est de contribuer à investiguer le rôle de toute sortes de protéines dans la perméabilité de l’intestin. Pour ce faire, je travaille à développer une stratégie rapide et polyvalente nous permettant de marquer ces protéines, question de déterminer leur organisation spatiotemporelle en super-résolution. Bien qu’en pensant aux neurosciences, on ne pense pas automatiquement à l’intestin, des études récentes ont permis de mettre en évidence le lien étroit entre la perméabilité intestinale et la barrière hémato-encéphalique.

AntoineO.name: Antoine Séverin Ollier
AntoineO.info: After obtaining my degree in Engineering from Télécom Saint-Étienne in France, I decided to continue my studies in the field of microscopy and machine learning. I decided to join a multidisciplinary lab because I was interested in collaborating with other scientists. In my Master’s degree project, I am working on implementing a new type of detector that will allow us to make temporal and hyperspectral images on the STED microscope. I’m also working on machine learning algorithms that will enhance the amount of acquired signal in low-photon conditions.

Catherine.name: Catherine Bouchard
Catherine.info: After a bachelor's degree in engineering physics, I'm pursuing my studies in the field of machine learning to extend my knowledge to new methods applied to subjects I was already passionate about, such as photonics and life science. My project focuses specifically on the application of deep neural networks for algorithmic super-resolution of fluorescence microscopy images.

Frederic.name: Frédéric Beaupré
Frederic.info: The main endeavour of my project is to develop new and improved anomaly detection methods designed for the detection of early signs of neurodegeneration (in Parkinson’s disease and ALS) in synaptic populations, and the discovery of new biomarkers associated with the neurodegenerative diseases. The striking similarities between optical brain imaging and astronomical data motivates our drawing inspiration from deep-learning-based methods in the latter field for developing our image acquisition and anomaly detection approaches.

JM.name: Jean-Michel Bellavance
JM.info: During my first year of bachelor’s degree in Microbiology, I completed a summer internship in a neuroscience laboratory where I learned the patch-clamp technique. I loved participating in this experience because of the challenge of being immersed in a field that I knew almost nothing of with a task as hard as to complete a patch-clamp project during the summer. My interest in psychology also further motivated me to start a master’s degree in Neuroscience. In Flavie’s lab, I will now combine STED microscopy and functional imaging to try to elucidate causal mechanisms of different diseases like ALS and Parkinson’s disease. I will focus on synaptic symptoms in these disease models.

Julia.name: Julia Chabbert
Julia.info: Interested in understanding the functioning of the brain, I completed a master's degree in neuroscience at the University of Bordeaux (France). My background in neuroscience directed my interests towards the discovery of the infinitely small. Indeed, connection interfaces between neurons, named synapses, replete proteins highly active to ensure good cell communication. Thus, my PhD project, co-supervised by Dr. Flavie Lavoie-Cardinal and Dr. Paul De Koninck, is to identify the molecular mechanisms underlying the remodeling of the synaptic cytoskeleton during long-term potentiation, a phenomenon involved in memory. In this aim, super-resolution microscopy is a considerable asset.

Katrine.name: Katrine Castonguay
Katrine.info: Détection des segmentations d'événements calciques par apprentissage profond dans des images de microscopie de diverses modalités

Kamylle.name: Kamylle Thériault
Kamylle.info: I greatly enjoy putting the 'multi' in multidisciplinary. Between analysing mitochondrial morphology in a human model of Parkinson's disease in 2022 and classifying antibacterial mode of action using deep learning in 2023, I’m always eager to find more ways to create a happy marriage between biology and informatics. My project mainly focuses on the informative relevance of channels in bi-modal microscopy images and the optimization of the efficiency of deep learning models trained solely on a small dataset.

Owen.name: Owen Ferguson
Owen.info: Parkinson’s disease affects more than 10 million people worldwide, and I’m interested in the mechanisms that lead to the death of dopamine-producing neurons in the disease. I am using stem cells from human patients to create neurons with Parkinson’s disease traits and I am using super-resolution microscopy to observe the differences between the mitochondria of healthy people and Parkinson’s disease patients.

Valerie.name: Valérie Clavet-Fournier
Valerie.info: My fascination for neuroscience appeared during my bachelor’s degree in biochemistry where I got the opportunity to do an internship with Paul De Koninck. I learned a lot about the learning and memory process via glutamatergic transmission and synaptic plasticity. I got so interested in the subject that it became the heart of my master’s project which was to elucidate the role of calpain in synaptic transmission. I pursued my PhD degree in the same fascinating field of neuroscience where I studied the structural remodeling of synaptic proteins with super-resolution STED microscopy after activity-driven plasticity of glutamatergic synapses in organotypic slices. With my background, I am now really glad to work in the FLC lab on the structural plasticity of synaptic proteins using STED microscopy and correlate those changes with the local activity of the neurons.

William.name: William Leclerc
William.info: During my bachelor's degree in bioinformatics, I was introduced to the symbiosis between the field of machine learning and several aspects of neuroscience. My interests now revolve around what artificial intelligence, and particularly deep learning, can teach us about living organisms and the ways they learn. My master's project focuses more specifically on the detection of anomalies related to bacteria in culture. I aspire to combine my approaches from diverse fields to open the way to bold and multidisciplinary ideas.

Elodie.name: Élodie Moth
Elodie.Title: Développement d’un module d’anisotropie de fluorescence pour l’étude de la structure des neurones.

Eric.name: Éric Bergeron
Eric.info: Programmer, computer scientist, world traveler, CDT thru-hiker, co-founder of Echovita and Funerago, I am currently finishing my master's degree in artificial intelligence (AI). Knowing several people dealing with a neurodegenerative disease, I decided to apply my AI knowledge to the cause. I work on automatic instance segmentation of microglial cells in 3D images. This will allow scientists to quantify the gut's impact on microglia during the development of larval zebrafish.

Renaud.name: Renaud Bernatchez
Renaud.info: While completing internships in the lab during my bachelor’s degree in bioinformatics, I became fascinated with the application of deep learning to analyse microscopy images. However, such approaches require large amounts of painstakingly annotated data. The goal of my master’s degree is to use active learning to reduce the amount of annotated data required to train deep learning models to analyse fluorescence microscopy images.
Renaud.Project: Génération et analyse de jeux de données adaptés à l'application de l’apprentissage automatique en biophotonique

Samuel.name: Samuel Gagnon

Theresa.name: Theresa Wiesner
Theresa.Project: Quantitative assessment of synaptic plasticity at the molecular scale with multimodal microscopy and computational tools
Theresa.info: Coming from cancer research with focus on high throughput screening for drug development in the early years of my bachelor, I got fascinated during an internship with functional assays such as field recordings to study neuronal cell behaviour. I got hooked on doing my master in bio-photonics to learn functional imaging. During my PhD I combined functional assays, super-resolution imaging and computational tools to quantitatively assess and explore synaptic protein organization and remodeling due to synaptic plasticity. Being a scientist for me is not a job, but a lifestyle in which I can be continuously curious and explore across fields, be it from neuroscience, photonics to machine learning. In another life, I would be a diplomat who writes fiction books on the side.

Vincent.name: Vincent Boily
Vincent.info: For my master's project, I aim to refine a pipeline that will allow to combine whole-brain calcium imaging in larval zebrafish with visual stimulation, tail tracking and computational registration to brain atlases and postmortem immunostaining imaging to study the functional dynamics of the developing brain and the underlying contribution of specific neuromodulatory circuits in the context of learning and memory.
